Policy and Development Unit</AuthEnty>         <othId>P ; 1345Y</othId>         <othId>Ann Mair, under the direction of John Curtice (both of the Social Statistics Laboratory at the University of Strathclyde) was under contract to produce a SPSS set-up deck and system file.  Core-funding for the annual British Social Attitudes survey (of which YPSA 1994 is an offshoot) comes from the Sainsbury Family Charitable Trusts, and is supplemented by financial support from a number of other sources (see the BSA 1994 Technical Report), but final responsibility for the coverage and wording of the questionnaire remains SCPR's.</othId>       </rspStmt>       <prodStmt> vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/10e36836-e2c1-4bfe-8ddf-1c0055b191f1">YOUTH EMPLOYMENT</keyword>         <topcClas>Social indicators and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Youth - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The British Social Attitudes (BSA) survey series is designed to  complement large-scale government surveys such as the General Household Survey and the Labour Force Survey, which collect mainly factual and behavioural data. One of its main purposes is to allow the monitoring of patterns of continuity and change, and the examination of the relative rates at which attitudes, in respect of a range of social issues, change over time.<br> The Young People's Social Attitudes Survey (YPSA) is an offshoot of the 1994 BSA survey. It was designed to explore the attitudes and values of children and young people, and where possible to make comparisons with those held by adults in 1994. A further YPSA survey was carried out in 1998 as an offshoot of the 1998 BSA. It is held at the UK Data Archive under SN:4231.</abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br> Key topics covered included: age of consent; judgements of right and wrong; education, school life and sex education; crime and punishment; race prejudice and discrimination; family life and gender roles; political knowledge, political interest and political identity; important factors in 'doing well in life'; life ambitions and aspirations.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="1994-05-01T00:00:00Z">May 1994</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="1994-07-01T00:00:00Z">July 1994</collDate>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>Postcode (Sector)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Standard Statistical Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit>Young people aged 12-19 years.</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Young people</universe>         <universe>Young people (aged 12-19) living in the households of adults interviewed as part of the 1994 British Social Attitudes Survey. Addresses were sampled from the Postcode Address File (PAF).</universe>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Cross-sectional (one-time) study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>whilst not a regular series, another YPSA was carried out in 1998 (see SN:4231)</timeMeth>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>The weighted sample size was 580. The weighting reflected the relative selection probabilities of the individual at the three main stages of selection.
